subject: Art
title: White Balance
description: Making whites look white under any color of light.

hook.text: A photo taken indoors looks orange. A photo in shade looks blue. Your eyes auto-correct for different light colors, but cameras don't. White balance tells the camera what 'white' should look like in each lighting condition.

buildup.text: Measured in Kelvin: 2700K (warm/orange ‚Äî tungsten bulbs), 4000K (neutral ‚Äî fluorescent), 5500K (daylight), 6500K (cloudy ‚Äî slightly warm), 7500K+ (shade ‚Äî blue). Setting white balance to match the light makes colors accurate.

discovery.text: Auto white balance (AWB) works well 80% of the time. Shoot in RAW format and you can change white balance perfectly in post-processing ‚Äî it's one of the few settings that's fully recoverable after the shot.

twist.text: 'Wrong' white balance can be creative: setting tungsten balance outdoors makes everything deep blue (cool night feel). Setting daylight balance indoors with warm lights emphasizes the cozy warmth. 'Wrong' can be right.

climax.text: Take a photo under tungsten light with auto white balance (corrected, neutral) and then with daylight white balance (warm, orange). Same scene, completely different mood. White balance is a mood control.

punchline.text: White balance corrects color ‚Äî or creates it. The 'right' setting is the one that matches your vision.

quiz.question: Why do indoor photos under tungsten light often look orange?
options: Tungsten bulbs emit warm-colored light that the camera records without auto-correction from the eye
